Let's see.  It sounds like Max has got it pretty much covered.  So rather than
try to cover things in depth, I'll list (or re-state) things you can do to
check your levels:

1)      Make sure you've re-named both the 'scene' and 'grid' halves of the
level, as Max mentioned.  Both the names are listed on the right side of the
scenario editor; make sure they both show up as something different from the
default.  The 'scene' part MUST be named something like "scenX," where X is
the
level number (scen1, scen10, scen105, etc).  The 'grid' part can actually be
named anything you want (mygrid, tom99, etc.), but you might want to make it
match the 'scene' name.  Most importantly, it shouldn't be "test" (the
default)
or "scen0001" or whatever level you have loaded.
        So, for a test level number 138, I'd probably name both scene and grid
"scen138".

2)      After you've saved (or think you've saved) your scenario, from a DOS
prompt or Windows window, see if you have two new files: a .FSS file and a
.PIX
file.  These should be "scene.FSS" and "grid.PIX" to match the example above. 
So using the above examples, you should have "scen138.FSS" and "scen138.PIX"
files added.  If you don't, this is where the problem is coming in.

3)      If the level doesn't load correctly in Gladiator, try re-loading it
using the scenario editor.  If it doesn't load correctly there, either,
then it
probably wasn't saved correctly.  This may mean that your "GLAD.CFG" file
doesn't have the correct information entered in it; you can correct this by
re-running Gladiator's SETUP.EXE program, and specifying the correct drive
letter and path.  Remember that Gladiator is a DOS (not Windows) based
game, so
that folder/directory names (a) can't have spaces or funny characters in them,
and (b) must be 8 letters or fewer in length.  So installing Gladiator to:
"C:\Program Files\My Games\Gladiator" will not work, while
"C:\Files\Games\Glad" will work fine.
        You can also see where the scenario editor THINKS it is installed by
adding "/?" when running it (that is, type "scen /?" at the command line.  It
will print out something like this:
        Scenario Editor version 3.8H
        Using Data directory: e:\gladr\
        NOTE: this is set in glad.cfg.
        Memory available: 130019328 bytes.

If the "data directory" is incorrect, that's where the problem is occuring. 
You can fix this by re-running setup.exe, or by editing the GLAD.CFG file
using
a text editor.

That's all I can think of for now .. hope it helps!

--Tom
